question_details.query: What actions can be taken to reduce predation by marine mammals at aquaculture systems?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Actions to reduce predation by marine mammals at aquaculture systems include replacing or repairing damaged anti-predator nets, which one study found resulted in fewer salmon losses to harbour seal predation when nets were replaced more frequently at salmon farms (Action 2774). Acoustic devices can be used at aquaculture systems, with studies showing that four of six studies found acoustic devices reduced predation on caged salmon by grey seals, harbour seals and South American sea lions, or reduced the number of harbour seals approaching fish cages, though two studies found they did not reduce harbour seal predation or affect common bottlenose dolphin behavior around fin-fish farms (Action 2775). Translocating mammals away from aquaculture systems has been attempted, though studies found that more than half or nearly all of Australian and New Zealand fur seals translocated away from salmon farms returned (Action 2776). Other potential actions include modifying anti-predator nets around aquaculture systems, minimizing food waste at aquaculture systems, and introducing regulations to prevent the use of harmful deterrents, though no studies were found evaluating the effectiveness of these approaches (Actions 2743, 2744, 2746).
summary_statements: Replacing or repairing damaged anti-predator nets is an action that can reduce predation by marine mammals at aquaculture systems.
One study found that replacing anti-predator nets more frequently at salmon farms resulted in fewer salmon losses to harbour seal predation.
Acoustic devices can be used at aquaculture systems.
Four of six studies found that acoustic devices reduced predation on caged salmon by grey seals, harbour seals and South American sea lions.
Some studies found that acoustic devices reduced the number of harbour seals approaching fish cages.
Two studies found that acoustic devices did not reduce harbour seal predation.
Two studies found that acoustic devices did not affect common bottlenose dolphin behavior around fin-fish farms.
Translocating mammals away from aquaculture systems has been attempted.
Studies found that more than half or nearly all of Australian and New Zealand fur seals translocated away from salmon farms returned.
Modifying anti-predator nets around aquaculture systems is a potential action to reduce predation.
Minimizing food waste at aquaculture systems is a potential action to reduce predation.
Introducing regulations to prevent the use of harmful deterrents is a potential action to reduce predation.
No studies were found evaluating the effectiveness of modifying anti-predator nets, minimizing food waste at aquaculture systems, or introducing regulations to prevent the use of harmful deterrents.

question_details.query: Which modifications to fishing gear are most effective at reducing marine mammal entanglement?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Based on the available studies, several fishing gear modifications show effectiveness at reducing marine mammal entanglement. Deploying fishing gear at different depths proved effective, with one controlled study in the Arafura Sea finding that fishing nets deployed 4.5 m below the water surface had fewer entanglements of dolphins than surface nets (Action 2793). Acoustically reflective fishing gear materials demonstrated mixed but promising results, with two of three controlled studies in the North Sea, Bay of Fundy and South Atlantic Ocean finding that fishing nets made from acoustically reflective materials (iron-oxide or barium sulfate) had fewer entanglements of harbour porpoises than conventional fishing nets, though one study found that barium sulfate nets did not reduce dolphin entanglements (Action 2807). Catch and hook protection devices showed effectiveness for certain species, with one study in the South Pacific Ocean finding that using cage or chain devices on fishing hooks resulted in fewer unwanted catches of toothed whales (Action 2821). However, several other modification approaches showed no evidence of effectiveness: stiffened materials or increased tension in fishing nets did not reduce Franciscana dolphin entanglements in one controlled study in the South Atlantic Ocean (Action 2801). Several potential modifications including biodegradable fishing gear, weakened fishing gear, smaller mesh sizes, and limiting fishing gear length have no available studies evaluating their effectiveness on marine mammal populations (Actions 2885, 2797, 2802, 2795).
summary_statements: Several fishing gear modifications show effectiveness at reducing marine mammal entanglement.
Deploying fishing gear at different depths proved effective at reducing marine mammal entanglement.
A controlled study in the Arafura Sea found that fishing nets deployed 4.5 m below the water surface had fewer entanglements of dolphins than surface nets.
Acoustically reflective fishing gear materials demonstrated mixed but promising results in reducing marine mammal entanglement.

Two of three controlled studies found that fishing nets made from acoustically reflective materials, such as iron-oxide or barium sulfate, had fewer entanglements of harbour porpoises than conventional fishing nets.
One study found that barium sulfate nets did not reduce dolphin entanglements.
Catch and hook protection devices showed effectiveness for certain species.
One study in the South Pacific Ocean found that using cage or chain devices on fishing hooks resulted in fewer unwanted catches of toothed whales.
Several other modification approaches showed no evidence of effectiveness.
Stiffened materials or increased tension in fishing nets did not reduce Franciscana dolphin entanglements in one controlled study.
There are no available studies evaluating the effectiveness of biodegradable fishing gear on marine mammal populations.
There are no available studies evaluating the effectiveness of weakened fishing gear on marine mammal populations.
There are no available studies evaluating the effectiveness of smaller mesh sizes on marine mammal populations.
There are no available studies evaluating the effectiveness of limiting fishing gear length on marine mammal populations.

question_details.query: What are the population-level effects of legally protecting marine mammal species or their habitats?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Studies have documented several population-level effects of legal protection for marine mammals and their habitats. Legal habitat protection showed positive population responses in four studies across different regions (action ID 2915). One study in the North Atlantic Ocean found that Mediterranean monk seal populations increased during eight years after their inhabited islands were legally protected (action ID 2915). Another study in the South Pacific Ocean found that Hector's dolphin survival rates were higher after a coastal area was legally protected than before protection (action ID 2915). However, one study in the North Sea found that bottlenose dolphin population size remained similar before and after part of their range was protected (action ID 2915). A study in the Port River estuary found that after legal protection, similar numbers of Indo-Pacific bottlenose dolphin strandings were recorded compared to before protection, but human-caused strandings decreased (action ID 2915).

Prohibiting hunting of marine mammal species demonstrated strong population effects in five studies (action ID 2780). Four of five studies found that after hunting was prohibited, harbor seal and humpback whale abundance increased over 7-30 years in the Kattegat and Skagerrak Seas, South Pacific Ocean, North Atlantic Ocean, and Southern Ocean (action ID 2780). One review covering the North Atlantic Ocean, North Pacific Ocean and Southern Hemisphere found significant increase rates for 10 of 12 baleen whale populations during 7-21 years after legislation prohibiting hunting was introduced (action ID 2780). However, one study found that mature male sperm whale numbers did not differ significantly before or 31 years after hunting was prohibited (action ID 2780).

Prohibiting activities that cause disturbance in sensitive areas showed positive effects in limited studies (action ID 2917). One study in the Kattegat Sea found that harbor porpoise activity increased at a stony reef after fishing was prohibited and the reef was restored (action ID 2917). One study in the Indian Ocean found that a beach with fully prohibited human access had fewer Australian sea lions showing aggression or retreating compared to a beach with partial access restrictions (action ID 2917).

No studies were found that evaluated the effects of directly legally protecting marine and freshwater mammal species (action ID 2923), enforcing existing legislation for habitat protection (action ID 2916), or establishing networks of legally protected areas (action ID 2913).
summary_statements: Studies have documented several population-level effects of legal protection for marine mammals and their habitats.
Legal habitat protection showed positive population responses in four studies across different regions.
A study in the North Atlantic Ocean found that Mediterranean monk seal populations increased during eight years after the islands the seals inhabited were legally protected.
A study in the South Pacific Ocean found that Hector's dolphin survival rates were higher after a coastal area was legally protected than before the area was protected.
One study in the North Sea found that bottlenose dolphin population size remained similar before and after part of the bottlenose dolphins' range was protected.
A study in the Port River estuary found that after legal protection, similar numbers of Indo-Pacific bottlenose dolphin strandings were recorded compared to before protection was in place.
A study in the Port River estuary found that after legal protection, human-caused strandings of Indo-Pacific bottlenose dolphins decreased.
Prohibiting hunting of marine mammal species demonstrated strong population effects in five studies.

Four of five studies found that after hunting was prohibited, harbor seal and humpback whale abundance increased over 7-30 years in the Kattegat and Skagerrak Seas, South Pacific Ocean, North Atlantic Ocean, and Southern Ocean.

One review covering the North Atlantic Ocean, North Pacific Ocean and Southern Hemisphere found significant increase rates for 10 of 12 baleen whale populations during 7-21 years after legislation prohibiting hunting was introduced.
One study found that mature male sperm whale numbers did not differ significantly before or 31 years after hunting was prohibited.
Prohibiting activities that cause disturbance in sensitive areas showed positive effects in limited studies.
One study in the Kattegat Sea found that harbor porpoise activity increased at a stony reef after fishing was prohibited and the reef was restored.
A study in the Indian Ocean found that a beach with fully prohibited human access had fewer Australian sea lions showing aggression or retreating compared to a beach with partial access restrictions.
No studies were found that evaluated the effects of directly legally protecting marine and freshwater mammal species.
No studies were found that evaluated the effects of enforcing existing legislation for habitat protection.
No studies were found that evaluated the effects of establishing networks of legally protected areas.

question_details.query: What is the state of the evidence for interventions aimed at reducing lethal vessel collisions with marine mammals?

summary_details.relevant_summary: The evidence for interventions aimed at reducing lethal vessel collisions with marine mammals is extremely limited. Among the various intervention strategies examined, only setting and enforcing vessel speed limits has been evaluated with actual evidence. Two studies evaluated the effects of setting and enforcing vessel speed limits (Action ID: 2777): one before-and-after study in the Indian River estuarine system found similar numbers of manatee deaths before and after vessel speed limits were set in 'zones', but fewer deaths were recorded after speed limits were set and enforced in all areas; and one before-and-after study in the North Atlantic Ocean found that setting vessel speed limits during specific periods in key habitats resulted in fewer North Atlantic right whale deaths caused by collisions. For all other potential interventions, no studies were found evaluating their effectiveness, including: diverting shipping routes (Action ID: 2754), using observers on board vessels to detect mammals (Action ID: 2755), reducing shipping along inland waterways (Action ID: 2763), developing and implementing regulations for operating vessels around mammals (Action ID: 2758), using remote tools to detect mammals (Action ID: 2757), using real-time automated tools on board vessels to detect mammals (Action ID: 2756), limiting vessel traffic in shallow rivers (Action ID: 2764), using acoustic devices on moving vessels (Action ID: 2761), and providing training to vessel operators on mammal behaviour and appropriate avoidance techniques (Action ID: 2759).
summary_statements: The evidence for interventions aimed at reducing lethal vessel collisions with marine mammals is extremely limited.
Among the various intervention strategies examined, only setting and enforcing vessel speed limits has been evaluated with actual evidence.
Two studies evaluated the effects of setting and enforcing vessel speed limits.
One before-and-after study in the Indian River estuarine system found similar numbers of manatee deaths before and after vessel speed limits were set in 'zones'.
Fewer manatee deaths were recorded in the Indian River estuarine system after speed limits were set and enforced in all areas.

A before-and-after study in the North Atlantic Ocean found that setting vessel speed limits during specific periods in key habitats resulted in fewer North Atlantic right whale deaths caused by collisions.
No studies were found evaluating the effectiveness of diverting shipping routes.
No studies were found evaluating the effectiveness of using observers on board vessels to detect mammals.
No studies were found evaluating the effectiveness of reducing shipping along inland waterways.
No studies were found evaluating the effectiveness of developing and implementing regulations for operating vessels around mammals.
No studies were found evaluating the effectiveness of using remote tools to detect mammals.
No studies were found evaluating the effectiveness of using real-time automated tools on board vessels to detect mammals.
No studies were found evaluating the effectiveness of limiting vessel traffic in shallow rivers.
No studies were found evaluating the effectiveness of using acoustic devices on moving vessels.
No studies were found evaluating the effectiveness of providing training to vessel operators on mammal behaviour and appropriate avoidance techniques.

question_details.query: How do the outcomes of translocating marine mammals vary depending on the conservation goal, based on studies from the Pacific and Tasman Sea regions?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Based on studies from the Pacific and Tasman Sea regions, marine mammal translocation outcomes vary significantly depending on conservation goals. For population re-establishment goals in the North Pacific Ocean, four studies on Hawaiian monk seals showed positive outcomes: 50-83% of translocated seal pups survived for at least one year, with translocated pups having similar survival rates to non-translocated pups born at release sites or greater survival rates than non-translocated pups remaining at the original site. More than a quarter of translocated Hawaiian monk seals reproduced, and more than a quarter survived when translocation was combined with at least seven other survival enhancement interventions. Translocated Hawaiian monk seal pups also showed similar dispersal times to non-translocated seal pups born at release sites (Action ID: 2930). In contrast, for human-wildlife conflict reduction goals in the Tasman Sea and Southern Ocean around Tasmania, two studies found that translocation was less effective: more than half or nearly all of Australian and New Zealand fur seals translocated away from salmon farms returned to the original location (Action ID: 2776).
summary_statements: Based on studies from the Pacific and Tasman Sea regions, marine mammal translocation outcomes vary significantly depending on conservation goals.
For population re-establishment goals in the North Pacific Ocean, studies on Hawaiian monk seals showed positive outcomes.
50-83% of translocated Hawaiian monk seal pups survived for at least one year.
Translocated Hawaiian monk seal pups had similar survival rates to non-translocated pups born at release sites.
Translocated Hawaiian monk seal pups had greater survival rates than non-translocated pups remaining at the original site.
More than a quarter of translocated Hawaiian monk seals reproduced.
More than a quarter of translocated Hawaiian monk seals survived when translocation was combined with at least seven other survival enhancement interventions.
Translocated Hawaiian monk seal pups showed similar dispersal times to non-translocated seal pups born at release sites.
For human-wildlife conflict reduction goals in the Tasman Sea and Southern Ocean around Tasmania, two studies found that translocation was less effective.
More than half of Australian and New Zealand fur seals translocated away from salmon farms returned to the original location.
Nearly all of Australian and New Zealand fur seals translocated away from salmon farms returned to the original location.

question_details.query: What is the evidence for the long-term survival of marine mammals following rescue or rehabilitation and release?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Evidence for long-term survival of marine mammals following rescue or rehabilitation and release comes from multiple studies. For rehabilitated and released injured, sick or weak marine mammals, 21 studies found that 10-100% of dolphins, porpoises, whales, seals, sea lions and manatees survived during post-release monitoring periods ranging from three days to five years (Action 2925). For rescued and released stranded or trapped marine mammals, seven studies found that 17-100% of Atlantic white-sided dolphins, short-beaked common dolphins, common bottlenose dolphins, long-finned pilot whales, short-finned pilot whales, and Cape fur seals survived during post-release monitoring periods ranging from three weeks to three years (Action 2924). 

Specific long-term survival evidence includes: more than a quarter of rehabilitated and released Hawaiian monk seals reproduced (Action 2925), a stranded common bottlenose dolphin was observed with a calf a year later after rescue and release (Action 2924), and more than a quarter of Hawaiian monk seals survived after rescue, release and other interventions (Action 2924). For hand-reared orphaned mammals, approximately three-quarters of Antillean manatees and two-thirds of Florida manatees that were captive-reared and released were known to survive for at least one year, with some surviving for more than seven years (Action 2926). Captive-reared and released Pacific harbour seal pups had similar survival estimates to wild pups (Action 2926). For captive-bred releases, two of three Antillean manatees and two of 14 Florida manatees born in captivity survived for at least one year without further intervention (Action 2933).
summary_statements: Evidence for long-term survival of marine mammals following rescue or rehabilitation and release comes from multiple studies.
In 21 studies of rehabilitated and released injured, sick or weak marine mammals, 10-100% of dolphins, porpoises, whales, seals, sea lions and manatees survived.
The survival of these rehabilitated marine mammals was monitored during post-release periods ranging from three days to five years.

In seven studies of rescued and released stranded or trapped marine mammals, 17-100% of Atlantic white-sided dolphins, short-beaked common dolphins, common bottlenose dolphins, long-finned pilot whales, short-finned pilot whales, and Cape fur seals survived.
The survival of these rescued marine mammals was monitored during post-release periods ranging from three weeks to three years.
More than a quarter of rehabilitated and released Hawaiian monk seals reproduced.
A stranded common bottlenose dolphin was observed with a calf a year after its rescue and release.
More than a quarter of Hawaiian monk seals survived after rescue, release and other interventions.
Approximately three-quarters of Antillean manatees that were captive-reared and released were known to survive for at least one year.
Approximately two-thirds of Florida manatees that were captive-reared and released were known to survive for at least one year.
Some captive-reared and released manatees survived for more than seven years.
Captive-reared and released Pacific harbour seal pups had similar survival estimates to wild pups.
Two of three Antillean manatees born in captivity survived for at least one year without further intervention after release.
Two of fourteen Florida manatees born in captivity survived for at least one year without further intervention after release.

question_details.query: What actions are available to reduce human-wildlife conflict at commercial fisheries in riverine systems?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Several actions are available to reduce human-wildlife conflict at commercial fisheries in riverine systems based on documented studies:

PHYSICAL BARRIERS: Installing barriers at wild fisheries has been tested, though one study in the Puntledge River found that installing a 'cork line' barrier did not deter harbour seals from feeding on salmon released from a hatchery (Action 2824). Anti-predator nets can be effective when properly maintained - replacing anti-predator nets more frequently at salmon farms resulted in fewer salmon losses to harbour seal predation according to one study in the North Atlantic Ocean (Action 2774).

ACOUSTIC DETERRENTS: Acoustic devices show mixed effectiveness. At aquaculture systems, four of six studies found that acoustic devices reduced predation on caged salmon by grey seals, harbour seals and South American sea lions, or reduced the number of harbour seals approaching fish cages, though two studies found no effect on harbour seal predation or dolphin presence (Action 2775). On fishing gear, acoustic devices showed better results - nine studies found they resulted in fewer entanglements of harbour porpoises, Franciscana dolphins, beaked whales and small cetaceans, and five of six studies found they reduced damage to fish catches and fishing nets caused by dolphins and seals (Action 2808). On fishing vessels, acoustic devices had limited success for conflict reduction, with only one study finding no reduction in predation of squid catches by dolphins (Action 2815).

LIGHTING MODIFICATIONS: Switching off artificial lighting at wild fisheries was tested in one study in the Puntledge River, but did not deter harbour seals from feeding on salmon released from a hatchery (Action 2825).

TRANSLOCATION: Translocating mammals away from aquaculture systems has limited long-term effectiveness, as studies in the Tasman Sea found that more than half or nearly all of translocated Australian and New Zealand fur seals returned to salmon farms (Action 2776).

REGULATORY APPROACHES: Two regulatory actions to prevent harmful deterrents at aquaculture systems and wild fisheries exist but have no documented studies evaluating their effectiveness (Actions 2746, 2779).
summary_statements: Several actions are available to reduce human-wildlife conflict at commercial fisheries in riverine systems based on documented studies.
Installing barriers at wild fisheries has been tested.
A study in the Puntledge River found that installing a 'cork line' barrier did not deter harbour seals from feeding on salmon released from a hatchery.
Anti-predator nets can be effective when properly maintained.
A study in the North Atlantic Ocean found that replacing anti-predator nets more frequently at salmon farms resulted in fewer salmon losses to harbour seal predation.
Acoustic devices show mixed effectiveness.
At aquaculture systems, some studies found that acoustic devices reduced predation on caged salmon by grey seals, harbour seals and South American sea lions.
Some studies at aquaculture systems found acoustic devices reduced the number of harbour seals approaching fish cages.
Two studies found that acoustic devices had no effect on harbour seal predation or dolphin presence at aquaculture systems.
On fishing gear, studies found acoustic devices resulted in fewer entanglements of harbour porpoises, Franciscana dolphins, beaked whales and small cetaceans.
Studies found acoustic devices on fishing gear reduced damage to fish catches and fishing nets caused by dolphins and seals.
On fishing vessels, acoustic devices had limited success for conflict reduction.
One study found that acoustic devices on fishing vessels did not reduce the predation of squid catches by dolphins.
Switching off artificial lighting at wild fisheries was tested in one study in the Puntledge River.
Switching off artificial lighting did not deter harbour seals from feeding on salmon released from a hatchery in one study.
Translocating mammals away from aquaculture systems has limited long-term effectiveness.
Studies in the Tasman Sea found that more than half or nearly all of translocated Australian and New Zealand fur seals returned to salmon farms.
Regulatory actions to prevent harmful deterrents at aquaculture systems and wild fisheries exist.
The effectiveness of two existing regulatory actions to prevent harmful deterrents at aquaculture systems and wild fisheries has not been evaluated in documented studies.

question_details.query: What is the evidence for the success of interventions like translocation and rehabilitation for Hawaiian monk seals in the North Pacific Ocean?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Evidence for translocation success of Hawaiian monk seals in the North Pacific Ocean shows that 50-83% of translocated Hawaiian monk seal pups survived for at least one year, and 52% of rehabilitated and translocated pups survived for at least one year (Action 2930). Translocated seal pups had similar survival rates to non-translocated pups born at release sites or greater survival rates than non-translocated pups remaining at the original site (Action 2930). More than a quarter of translocated Hawaiian monk seals reproduced when combined with rehabilitation or at least seven other interventions to enhance survival (Action 2930). Translocated Hawaiian monk seal pups had similar dispersal times to non-translocated seal pups born at release sites (Action 2930). 

Evidence for rehabilitation success shows that more than a quarter of rehabilitated and released Hawaiian monk seals reproduced (Action 2925). Studies found that 10-100% of seals released after rehabilitation in captivity survived during post-release monitoring periods ranging from three days to five years (Action 2925). Removing aggressive male Hawaiian monk seals increased the survival of adult female Hawaiian monk seals and resulted in fewer female Hawaiian monk seals being injured (Action 2929). Reuniting Hawaiian monk seal pups with their mothers, along with at least seven other interventions to enhance survival, resulted in more than a quarter of the seals reproducing and surviving (Action 2927). Rescuing and releasing stranded or trapped Hawaiian monk seals, along with at least seven other interventions to enhance survival, resulted in more than a quarter of the seals reproducing and surviving (Action 2924).
summary_statements: 50-83% of translocated Hawaiian monk seal pups survived for at least one year.
52% of rehabilitated and translocated Hawaiian monk seal pups survived for at least one year.
Translocated Hawaiian monk seal pups had similar survival rates to non-translocated pups born at release sites.
Translocated Hawaiian monk seal pups had greater survival rates than non-translocated pups remaining at the original site.
More than a quarter of translocated Hawaiian monk seals reproduced when combined with rehabilitation or at least seven other interventions to enhance survival.
Translocated Hawaiian monk seal pups had similar dispersal times to non-translocated seal pups born at release sites.
More than a quarter of rehabilitated and released Hawaiian monk seals reproduced.
Studies found that 10-100% of Hawaiian monk seals released after rehabilitation in captivity survived during post-release monitoring periods ranging from three days to five years.
Removing aggressive male Hawaiian monk seals increased the survival of adult female Hawaiian monk seals.
Removing aggressive male Hawaiian monk seals resulted in fewer female Hawaiian monk seals being injured.
Reuniting Hawaiian monk seal pups with their mothers, along with at least seven other interventions to enhance survival, resulted in more than a quarter of the seals reproducing.
Reuniting Hawaiian monk seal pups with their mothers, along with at least seven other interventions to enhance survival, resulted in more than a quarter of the seals surviving.
Rescuing and releasing stranded or trapped Hawaiian monk seals, along with at least seven other interventions to enhance survival, resulted in more than a quarter of the seals reproducing.
Rescuing and releasing stranded or trapped Hawaiian monk seals, along with at least seven other interventions to enhance survival, resulted in more than a quarter of the seals surviving.

question_details.query: What are the non-lethal alternatives for managing marine mammal presence and predation at aquaculture facilities, and how effective are they?

summary_details.relevant_summary: The non-lethal alternatives for managing marine mammal presence and predation at aquaculture facilities include acoustic devices, anti-predator nets, translocation, and diversionary feeding. Acoustic devices at aquaculture systems showed mixed effectiveness across six studies in the North Atlantic Ocean, Chile, and Mediterranean Sea - four studies found that acoustic devices reduced predation on caged salmon by grey seals, harbour seals and South American sea lions, or reduced the number of harbour seals approaching fish cages, while two studies found no reduction in harbour seal predation or in the presence of common bottlenose dolphins around fin-fish farms (Action 2775). Anti-predator nets are used as physical barriers, with one study in the North Atlantic Ocean finding that replacing anti-predator nets more frequently at salmon farms resulted in fewer salmon losses to harbour seal predation (Action 2774). However, no studies were found evaluating the effects of modifying anti-predator nets around aquaculture systems (Action 2743). Translocation of mammals away from aquaculture systems was evaluated in two studies in the Tasman Sea and Southern Ocean, but showed limited effectiveness as more than half or nearly all of Australian and New Zealand fur seals translocated away from salmon farms returned (Action 2776). Diversionary feeding to reduce nuisance behaviour and human-wildlife conflict was studied with mammals, with two studies in the USA finding that diversionary feeding reduced nuisance behaviour by black bears (Action 2323). Other potential alternatives include minimizing food waste at aquaculture systems and modifying aquaculture gear, but no studies were found evaluating their effects on marine and freshwater mammal populations (Actions 2744, 2742). Installing barriers at wild fisheries showed poor results, with one study finding that a cork line barrier did not deter harbour seals from feeding on salmon released from a hatchery (Action 2824).
summary_statements: The non-lethal alternatives for managing marine mammal presence and predation at aquaculture facilities include acoustic devices, anti-predator nets, translocation, and diversionary feeding.
Acoustic devices at aquaculture systems showed mixed effectiveness across several studies.
Four studies found that acoustic devices reduced predation on caged salmon by grey seals, harbour seals and South American sea lions.
Some studies found that acoustic devices reduced the number of harbour seals approaching fish cages.
Two studies found no reduction in harbour seal predation from the use of acoustic devices.
Two studies found no reduction in the presence of common bottlenose dolphins around fin-fish farms from the use of acoustic devices.
Anti-predator nets are used as physical barriers at aquaculture facilities.
One study found that replacing anti-predator nets more frequently at salmon farms resulted in fewer salmon losses to harbour seal predation.
No studies were found evaluating the effects of modifying anti-predator nets around aquaculture systems.
The translocation of mammals away from aquaculture systems showed limited effectiveness.
More than half or nearly all Australian and New Zealand fur seals translocated away from salmon farms returned.
Diversionary feeding has been studied to reduce nuisance behaviour and human-wildlife conflict with mammals.
Two studies in the USA found that diversionary feeding reduced nuisance behaviour by black bears.
Other potential alternatives for managing marine mammals include minimizing food waste at aquaculture systems and modifying aquaculture gear.
No studies were found evaluating the effects of minimizing food waste or modifying aquaculture gear on marine and freshwater mammal populations.
Installing barriers at wild fisheries showed poor results for deterring marine mammals.
One study found that a cork line barrier did not deter harbour seals from feeding on salmon released from a hatchery.

question_details.query: What are the most beneficial non-lethal methods for reducing human-wildlife conflict at wild fisheries involving seals?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Based on the available evidence from action documents, several non-lethal methods have been evaluated for reducing human-wildlife conflict involving seals at wild fisheries:

Physical modifications to fishing equipment: Action 2822 found that installing steel rods on lobster pots or metal frames on fishing pots reduced the number of Australian sea lion pups or grey seals and harbour seals that entered or became trapped in pots. Action 2822 also showed that installing wire grids or steel bars on fishing trap-nets or bag-nets, along with strengthened netting or other modifications to prevent seal access, reduced damage to salmon catches by seals. Action 2823 demonstrated that installing exclusion and/or escape devices on trawl nets reduced the number of trapped or entangled Antarctic fur seals, and that fewer fur seals died in exclusion devices with large escape openings than in those with small openings.

Acoustic deterrents: Action 2808 found that using acoustic devices on fishing nets resulted in seals approaching nets less closely, having fewer encounters or interactions with nets, or reduced activity and sightings in the surrounding area. Action 2808 also showed that acoustic devices reduced damage to fish catches and/or fishing nets caused by seals. Action 2816 found that deploying an acoustic device on a mooring reduced the number of harbour seals feeding on migrating juvenile salmon. Action 2816 also showed that deploying acoustic devices on moorings reduced numbers of grey and harbour seals.

Methods with limited effectiveness: Action 2824 found that installing a 'cork line' barrier did not deter harbour seals from feeding on salmon released from a hatchery. Action 2825 found that switching off artificial lights on a bridge did not deter harbour seals from feeding on salmon released from a hatchery. Action 2806 found that attaching acrylic beads next to fishing hooks did not reduce predation on fish catches by sperm whales.
summary_statements: Several non-lethal methods have been evaluated for reducing human-wildlife conflict involving seals at wild fisheries.
Installing steel rods on lobster pots or metal frames on fishing pots reduced the number of Australian sea lion pups or grey seals and harbour seals that entered or became trapped in pots.
Installing wire grids or steel bars on fishing trap-nets or bag-nets, along with strengthened netting or other modifications to prevent seal access, reduced damage to salmon catches by seals.
Installing exclusion and/or escape devices on trawl nets reduced the number of trapped or entangled Antarctic fur seals.
Fewer fur seals died in exclusion devices with large escape openings than in those with small openings.
Using acoustic devices on fishing nets resulted in seals approaching nets less closely, having fewer encounters or interactions with nets, or reduced activity and sightings in the surrounding area.
Acoustic devices reduced damage to fish catches and/or fishing nets caused by seals.
Deploying an acoustic device on a mooring reduced the number of harbour seals feeding on migrating juvenile salmon.
Deploying acoustic devices on moorings reduced numbers of grey and harbour seals.
Installing a 'cork line' barrier did not deter harbour seals from feeding on salmon released from a hatchery.
Switching off artificial lights on a bridge did not deter harbour seals from feeding on salmon released from a hatchery.
Attaching acrylic beads next to fishing hooks did not reduce predation on fish catches by sperm whales.

question_details.query: Besides acoustic deterrents, what alternative physical modifications can be made to fishing gear to reduce porpoise and dolphin entanglement?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Physical modifications to fishing gear for reducing porpoise and dolphin entanglement include several approaches. Gillnet or entangling net configuration can be modified through reduced height, increased tension, twine diameter and mesh size and orientation changes (action 2701). Fishing nets can be made from acoustically reflective materials containing iron-oxide or barium sulfate, with two of three controlled studies showing fewer harbour porpoise entanglements compared to conventional nets (action 2807). Fishing gear can be deployed at different depths, with one study showing that nets deployed 4.5 m below the water surface had fewer dolphin entanglements than surface nets (action 2793). Exclusion and/or escape devices can be installed on fishing nets, with studies showing reduced trapped or entangled Antarctic fur seals and common bottlenose dolphins, and that larger escape openings resulted in fewer fur seal deaths than smaller openings (action 2823). Different twine types can be used in trawl nets, with studies examining effects of twine thickness and construction material on selectivity (action 2710). Additionally, lights can be added to fishing gear, though studies focused on turtle bycatch reduction rather than marine mammals (action 3554).
summary_statements: Physical modifications to fishing gear for reducing porpoise and dolphin entanglement include several approaches.
Gillnet or entangling net configuration can be modified through reduced height, increased tension, twine diameter and mesh size and orientation changes.
Fishing nets can be made from acoustically reflective materials containing iron-oxide or barium sulfate.
Two of three controlled studies showed that nets made from acoustically reflective materials led to fewer harbour porpoise entanglements compared to conventional nets.
Fishing gear can be deployed at different depths.
One study showed that nets deployed 4.5 meters below the water surface had fewer dolphin entanglements than surface nets.
Exclusion and/or escape devices can be installed on fishing nets.
Studies have shown that installing exclusion or escape devices on fishing nets reduced the number of trapped or entangled Antarctic fur seals and common bottlenose dolphins.
Studies have shown that larger escape openings on fishing gear resulted in fewer fur seal deaths than smaller openings.
Different twine types can be used in trawl nets.
Studies have examined the effects of twine thickness and construction material on the selectivity of trawl nets.
Lights can be added to fishing gear.
Studies on adding lights to fishing gear have focused on turtle bycatch reduction rather than on marine mammals.

question_details.query: What management actions can reduce disturbance to marine mammals from tourism and recreational activities?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Based on the available evidence, several management actions can reduce disturbance to marine mammals from tourism and recreational activities: Introducing and enforcing regulations for marine and freshwater mammal watching tours has been shown to be effective, with four studies demonstrating that when whale-watching vessels followed approach regulations, fewer sperm whales and humpback whale pods changed their behaviours or avoided vessels compared to when regulations were not followed (Action 2838). Similarly, when tour boats followed approach regulations, fewer Guiana dolphins displayed negative behaviours such as moving away, diving, or group separation (Action 2838). Additionally, when boats approached seal colonies to 75 meters versus 25 meters, more seals remained on shore (Action 2838). Setting and enforcing vessel speed limits has proven beneficial for marine mammal survival, with studies showing fewer manatee deaths after speed limits were set and enforced in all areas, and fewer North Atlantic right whale deaths caused by collisions when vessel speed limits were set during specific periods in key habitats (Action 2777). Other potential management actions include creating designated areas or access points for recreational activities (Action 2842), introducing permits or licences for recreational watersports (Action 2841) and marine mammal watching tours (Action 2839), developing regulations for operating vessels around mammals (Action 2758), delaying or ceasing operations if marine mammals are detected within specified zones (Action 2898), and controlling human activity in marine protected areas with zonation systems (Action 2674), though no studies were found evaluating the effectiveness of most of these actions on marine mammal populations.
summary_statements: Several management actions can reduce disturbance to marine mammals from tourism and recreational activities.
Introducing and enforcing regulations for marine and freshwater mammal watching tours has been shown to be effective.
When whale-watching vessels followed approach regulations, fewer sperm whales and humpback whale pods changed their behaviours or avoided vessels compared to when regulations were not followed.
When tour boats followed approach regulations, fewer Guiana dolphins displayed negative behaviours such as moving away, diving, or group separation.
When boats approached seal colonies to 75 meters versus 25 meters, more seals remained on shore.
Setting and enforcing vessel speed limits has proven beneficial for marine mammal survival.
Studies showed fewer manatee deaths after speed limits were set and enforced in all areas.
Fewer North Atlantic right whale deaths were caused by collisions when vessel speed limits were set during specific periods in key habitats.
Creating designated areas or access points for recreational activities is a potential management action to reduce disturbance to marine mammals.
Introducing permits or licences for recreational watersports is a potential management action to reduce disturbance to marine mammals.
Introducing permits or licences for marine mammal watching tours is a potential management action to reduce disturbance to marine mammals.
Developing regulations for operating vessels around mammals is a potential management action.
Delaying or ceasing operations if marine mammals are detected within specified zones is a potential management action.
Controlling human activity in marine protected areas with zonation systems is a potential management action.
No studies were found evaluating the effectiveness of many of the potential management actions on marine mammal populations.

question_details.query: What are the documented effects of translocating marine mammals for different conservation purposes?

summary_details.relevant_summary: The documented effects of translocating marine mammals for different conservation purposes show varied outcomes depending on the specific purpose. For population re-establishment or boosting native populations, four studies found that 50-83% of translocated Hawaiian monk seal pups survived for at least one year, with 52% of rehabilitated and translocated seals also surviving one year (Action 2930). Translocated seal pups had similar survival rates to non-translocated pups born at release sites or greater survival rates than non-translocated pups remaining at the original site, and more than a quarter of translocated seals reproduced (Action 2930). Translocated Hawaiian monk seal pups had similar dispersal times to non-translocated seal pups born at release sites (Action 2930). For translocation away from contaminated sites, one study found that most sea-otters survived for the duration of monitoring and most did not return to their capture location (Action 2542). For stress reduction during translocation, one study found that using tranquilizers did not increase post-release survival of European rabbits (Action 2465). For rehabilitation and release, 10-100% of dolphins, porpoises, whales, seals, sea lions and manatees released after rehabilitation survived during post-release monitoring periods ranging from three days to five years (Action 2925). More than a quarter of rehabilitated and released Hawaiian monk seals reproduced (Action 2925). Some rehabilitated animals showed similar movements and behaviors to wild mammals, while others showed behavioral differences such as traveling further from shore and making shorter, shallower dives (Action 2925). For captive-bred releases, two of three Antillean manatees and two of 14 Florida manatees born in captivity and released survived for at least one year without further intervention (Action 2933). However, no studies were found evaluating effects of translocation before onset of impactful activities, translocation to reduce disease exposure, or relocation following oil spills (Actions 2931, 2859, 2872, 2871).
summary_statements: The documented effects of translocating marine mammals for different conservation purposes show varied outcomes depending on the specific purpose.
For population re-establishment or boosting native populations, 50-83% of translocated Hawaiian monk seal pups survived for at least one year.
For population re-establishment, 52% of rehabilitated and translocated Hawaiian monk seals survived for one year.
Translocated Hawaiian monk seal pups had similar survival rates to non-translocated pups born at release sites.
Translocated Hawaiian monk seal pups had greater survival rates than non-translocated pups that remained at the original site.
More than a quarter of translocated Hawaiian monk seals reproduced.
Translocated Hawaiian monk seal pups had similar dispersal times to non-translocated seal pups born at release sites.
For translocation away from contaminated sites, most sea-otters survived for the duration of monitoring.
For translocation away from contaminated sites, most sea-otters did not return to their capture location.
For stress reduction during translocation, using tranquilizers did not increase post-release survival of European rabbits.

For rehabilitation and release, 10-100% of dolphins, porpoises, whales, seals, sea lions and manatees released after rehabilitation survived during post-release monitoring periods ranging from three days to five years.
More than a quarter of rehabilitated and released Hawaiian monk seals reproduced.
Some rehabilitated animals showed similar movements and behaviors to wild mammals.
Other rehabilitated animals showed behavioral differences such as traveling further from shore and making shorter, shallower dives.
For captive-bred releases, two of three Antillean manatees born in captivity and released survived for at least one year without further intervention.
For captive-bred releases, two of 14 Florida manatees born in captivity and released survived for at least one year without further intervention.
No studies were found evaluating the effects of translocation before the onset of impactful activities.
No studies were found evaluating the effects of translocation to reduce disease exposure.
No studies were found evaluating the effects of relocation following oil spills.

question_details.query: What is the state of the evidence regarding actions to reduce pollution from land-based agricultural and municipal sources affecting marine and freshwater mammals?

summary_details.relevant_summary: The evidence regarding actions to reduce pollution from land-based agricultural and municipal sources affecting marine and freshwater mammals shows a consistent lack of empirical studies. Across multiple relevant actions, no studies were found that evaluated their effects on marine and freshwater mammal populations. This includes agricultural pollution reduction actions such as treating wastewater from intensive livestock holdings (Action 2880), reducing pesticide, herbicide or fertilizer use (Action 2879), and regulating the use, dosage and disposal of agrichemicals (Action 2198). Similarly, for municipal pollution sources, no studies were found evaluating setting or improving minimum sewage treatment standards (Action 2867) or limiting storm wastewater overflow (Action 2868) on mammal populations. Infrastructure-based solutions also lack evidence, with no studies found for establishing riparian buffers to reduce pollutants reaching rivers and the sea (Action 2882), creating artificial wetlands to reduce pollutants reaching rivers and the sea (Action 2881), establishing aquaculture to extract nutrients from run-offs (Action 2883), or introducing and enforcing water quality regulations for aquaculture systems (Action 2876). The systematic searches conducted have been unable to assess whether these actions are effective or have any harmful impacts on marine and freshwater mammal populations.
summary_statements: The evidence regarding actions to reduce pollution from land-based agricultural and municipal sources affecting marine and freshwater mammals shows a consistent lack of empirical studies.
Across multiple relevant actions, no studies were found that evaluated the effects of these actions on marine and freshwater mammal populations.
No studies were found evaluating the effects of treating wastewater from intensive livestock holdings on marine and freshwater mammal populations.
No studies were found evaluating the effects of reducing pesticide, herbicide or fertilizer use on marine and freshwater mammal populations.
No studies were found evaluating the effects of regulating the use, dosage and disposal of agrichemicals on marine and freshwater mammal populations.
For municipal pollution sources, no studies were found evaluating the effects of setting or improving minimum sewage treatment standards on mammal populations.
For municipal pollution sources, no studies were found evaluating the effects of limiting storm wastewater overflow on mammal populations.
Infrastructure-based solutions to reduce pollution also lack evidence of their effects on mammal populations.
No studies were found for establishing riparian buffers to reduce pollutants reaching rivers and the sea.
No studies were found for creating artificial wetlands to reduce pollutants reaching rivers and the sea.
No studies were found for establishing aquaculture to extract nutrients from run-offs.
No studies were found for introducing and enforcing water quality regulations for aquaculture systems.
Systematic searches have been unable to assess whether pollution reduction actions are effective for marine and freshwater mammal populations.
Systematic searches have been unable to assess whether pollution reduction actions have any harmful impacts on marine and freshwater mammal populations.

question_details.query: What are the most beneficial interventions for reducing marine mammal bycatch in Australian fisheries?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Based on the action documents, several interventions have shown effectiveness for reducing marine mammal bycatch in Australian fisheries. Acoustic devices on fishing gear have been extensively studied and show promising results, with 14 studies demonstrating reduced entanglements of harbour porpoises, Franciscana dolphins, beaked whales and small cetaceans when acoustic devices were used on cod traps or fishing nets (Action 2808). In Australian waters specifically, studies in Moreton Bay, the Rainbow Channel and the Indian Ocean found that acoustic devices on fishing nets resulted in marine mammals approaching nets less closely and having fewer encounters (Action 2808). Deploying fishing gear at different depths has proven effective in Australian waters, with one controlled study in the Arafura Sea finding that fishing nets deployed 4.5 m below the water surface had fewer entanglements of dolphins than surface nets (Action 2793). Establishing handling and release protocols for captured mammals has shown measurable benefits, with one before-and-after study in the Great Australian Bight finding that introducing a code of conduct for releasing dolphins trapped in nets, along with avoiding dolphins during fishing, resulted in lower mortality of short-beaked common dolphins (Action 2829). Move-on rules for fishing vessels when mammals are encountered have demonstrated effectiveness in Australian waters, with the same Great Australian Bight study showing that measures to delay or relocate fishing if dolphins were encountered, along with releasing trapped dolphins, resulted in fewer short-beaked common dolphins being encircled and killed (Action 2790). Catch and hook protection devices have shown mixed results, with studies in the South Pacific Ocean (including Australia) finding that cage or chain devices on fishing hooks resulted in fewer unwanted catches of toothed whales, though effectiveness varied by device type (Action 2821). Acoustic devices on fishing vessels have been tested in Australian waters, with studies in the Rainbow Channel and Keppel Bay showing that acoustic devices deployed alongside vessels reduced surfacing and echolocation rates and time spent foraging or socializing of Indo-Pacific humpback dolphins and Australian snubfin dolphins (Action 2815).
summary_statements: Several interventions have shown effectiveness for reducing marine mammal bycatch in Australian fisheries.
Acoustic devices on fishing gear have been extensively studied and show promising results.
Studies demonstrated reduced entanglements of harbour porpoises, Franciscana dolphins, beaked whales and small cetaceans when acoustic devices were used on cod traps or fishing nets.

In Australian waters, studies in Moreton Bay, the Rainbow Channel and the Indian Ocean found that acoustic devices on fishing nets resulted in marine mammals approaching nets less closely and having fewer encounters.
Deploying fishing gear at different depths has proven effective in Australian waters.
A controlled study in the Arafura Sea found that fishing nets deployed 4.5 m below the water surface had fewer entanglements of dolphins than surface nets.
Establishing handling and release protocols for captured mammals has shown measurable benefits.
A study in the Great Australian Bight found that introducing a code of conduct for releasing dolphins trapped in nets resulted in lower mortality of short-beaked common dolphins.
The same study in the Great Australian Bight found that avoiding dolphins during fishing also resulted in lower mortality of short-beaked common dolphins.
Move-on rules for fishing vessels when mammals are encountered have demonstrated effectiveness in Australian waters.
A study in the Great Australian Bight showed that measures to delay or relocate fishing if dolphins were encountered resulted in fewer short-beaked common dolphins being encircled and killed.
Catch and hook protection devices have shown mixed results.
Studies in the South Pacific Ocean found that cage or chain devices on fishing hooks resulted in fewer unwanted catches of toothed whales.
The effectiveness of cage or chain devices on fishing hooks varied by device type.
Acoustic devices on fishing vessels have been tested in Australian waters.

Studies in the Rainbow Channel and Keppel Bay showed that acoustic devices deployed alongside vessels reduced surfacing and echolocation rates of Indo-Pacific humpback dolphins and Australian snubfin dolphins.

Studies in the Rainbow Channel and Keppel Bay also showed that acoustic devices deployed alongside vessels reduced the time that Indo-Pacific humpback dolphins and Australian snubfin dolphins spent foraging or socializing.

question_details.query: How does the evidence for mitigating seal predation differ between aquaculture systems and wild fisheries?

summary_details.relevant_summary: The evidence for mitigating seal predation differs significantly between aquaculture systems and wild fisheries in terms of available research and effectiveness of interventions. For aquaculture systems, the evidence shows that replacing anti-predator nets more frequently at salmon farms resulted in fewer salmon losses to harbour seal predation (Action 2774). Acoustic devices at aquaculture systems demonstrated mixed effectiveness, with four of six studies showing that using acoustic devices at salmon farms reduced predation on caged salmon by grey seals, harbour seals and South American sea lions, while two studies found that acoustic devices did not reduce harbour seal predation at salmon farms (Action 2775). Translocation of mammals away from aquaculture systems showed limited effectiveness, with more than half or nearly all of Australian and New Zealand fur seals translocated away from salmon farms returning (Action 2776). For wild fisheries, the evidence is more limited and shows different patterns. Modifying fishing pots and traps to exclude mammals showed positive results, with studies finding that installing steel rods on lobster pots or metal frames on fishing pots reduced the number of Australian sea lion pups or grey seals and harbour seals that entered or became trapped in pots, and that installing wire grids or steel bars on fishing trap-nets reduced damage to salmon catches by seals (Action 2822). Acoustic devices on moorings in wild fisheries showed variable effectiveness, with one randomized controlled study finding that deploying an acoustic device on a mooring reduced the number of harbour seals feeding on migrating juvenile salmon, while other studies showed mixed results on marine mammal behavior (Action 2816). However, installing barriers at wild fisheries and switching off artificial lighting at wild fisheries both showed no effectiveness, with studies finding that these measures did not deter harbour seals from feeding on salmon released from a hatchery (Actions 2824, 2825). Notably, no studies were found evaluating regulations to prevent harmful deterrents in either aquaculture systems or wild fisheries (Actions 2746, 2779).
summary_statements: The evidence for mitigating seal predation differs significantly between aquaculture systems and wild fisheries in terms of available research and effectiveness of interventions.
For aquaculture systems, replacing anti-predator nets more frequently at salmon farms resulted in fewer salmon losses to harbour seal predation.
Acoustic devices at aquaculture systems demonstrated mixed effectiveness in reducing seal predation.
Four of six studies showed that using acoustic devices at salmon farms reduced predation on caged salmon by grey seals, harbour seals and South American sea lions.
Two studies found that acoustic devices did not reduce harbour seal predation at salmon farms.
Translocation of mammals away from aquaculture systems showed limited effectiveness.
More than half or nearly all of Australian and New Zealand fur seals translocated away from salmon farms returned to the farms.
For wild fisheries, the evidence on mitigating seal predation is more limited and shows different patterns.
Modifying fishing pots and traps to exclude mammals showed positive results.

Studies found that installing steel rods on lobster pots or metal frames on fishing pots reduced the number of Australian sea lion pups or grey seals and harbour seals that entered or became trapped in pots.
Installing wire grids or steel bars on fishing trap-nets reduced damage to salmon catches by seals.
Acoustic devices on moorings in wild fisheries showed variable effectiveness.
One randomized controlled study found that deploying an acoustic device on a mooring reduced the number of harbour seals feeding on migrating juvenile salmon.
Other studies on acoustic devices in wild fisheries showed mixed results on marine mammal behavior.
Installing barriers at wild fisheries showed no effectiveness in deterring seals.
Switching off artificial lighting at wild fisheries showed no effectiveness in deterring seals.
Studies found that installing barriers and switching off artificial lighting did not deter harbour seals from feeding on salmon released from a hatchery.
No studies were found evaluating regulations to prevent harmful deterrents in either aquaculture systems or wild fisheries.
